story: NewsHMV closures: Full list of stores shutting down after signs appear across UKNine HMV stores are closing around the UK by the end of January including in the major cities of Birmingham, Plymouth and Leeds, in bid to re-jig business portfolioShareCommentsByLila Randall:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsHMV has put closing down signs in nine of its UK stores" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt least eight HMV stores are to be axed from the UK high street after the music giant quietly begun shutting down the venues last month. Word of the latest closures was spread by members of the public who posted photos of store closure signs in shop windows on social media. However, in many cases HMV has not made any public announcements. The outlets affected are in Leeds, Reading, Plymouth, the Bullring in Birmingham, Worcester, Bury St Edmunds, Grimsby and Nuneaton. The future of the following stores is currently unknown as HMV seeks to strike a deal with landlords: Bristol Cribbs, Edinburgh Ocean Terminal, Glasgow Braehead, Merryhill and Sheffield Meadowhall. If unsuccessful, they could shut.Reading’s HMV store in The Oracle launched a closing down sale on January , and closing down posters were put up in the mall. However, it is unclear whether the store is closing down for good or whether it’s relocating. Plymouth’s Drake Circus HMV is making way for a fresh retailer, leaving the centre on January  and re-opening in the former Maplin store in nearby Cornwall Street, also in the heart of the city centre.  One disappointed shopper wrote on Twitter : “My heart dropped when I saw the Closing sign, then realised they’re just moving, sad to see the store go by glad Plymouth will still have a HMV! #hmv” . Have you seen an HMV close down near you  Email webnews@mirror In Grimsby, the Freshney Place branch announced it will shut its doors later this month with for sale signs on almost all of its products and ‘store closing’ signs in its windows. However, HMV says it’s in talks with Freshney Place regarding the closures, and will inform customers “ anything changes”. A HMV spokesperson said: “At this time, talks are ongoing with the landlords involved and are currently progressing in a positive direction. “Thank you to the community for their ongoing support for us and we will let you knowanything changes.” Meanwhile, HMV in Worcester’s Crowngate Shopping Centre will close its doors on January  after the new business owner said the store was ‘no longer viable’.  A spokesman from HMV said: “Regretfully we can confirm that HMV Worcester will be closing, despite our desire to continue trading in this location.” HMV Nuneaton in the Ropewalk Shopping Centre will also close at the end of January after it was unable to agree a new deal with the landlord. Meanwhile, in Bury St Edmunds’ Arc Shopping Centre, the music will close its doors on January , and is rumoured to be making way for sports retailer JD Sports. HMV’s Birmingham store in the Bullring shopping centre is due to pull down its shutters at the end of January. Staff were told the opening of an HMV in the entertainment store at the fringe of the city centre, called HMV Vault, would eventually lead to the Bullring closure as its overheads are much higher. At the moment there isn’t a signicant sale at the store, though some prices have been discounted but many vinyl products have not. A statement issues by the Bullring shopping centre’s owner Hammerson said: “We can confirm that the HMV store at the Bullring is due to close. HMV recently opened Europeaposs largest entertainment store with Hammerson, HMV Vault, at Birmingham’s Dale End. Bury, which was also thought to be closing its store, announced on Twitter this morning that it would ‘stick around a lot longer’.  In December, HMV owner Doug Putman said Christmas was “crunch time” as the determiner of whether the handwork put into building the brand throughout the year pays off through festive sales. He told the BBC: ”All the hard work you do for  months of the year, that period is when you see it come to fruition and you see how good a job you did.

title: identical twin took life after
story: NewsIdentical twin took own le after three suicide attempts in less than a yearMatthew Siddorn, of Wirral, attempted to kill himself multiple times but his mum claims she couldnt get health authorities to take his mental health issues seriouslyShareCommentsByOlivia Williams:,  JAN NewsThe last photo Vicky took of her son, Matthew Siddorn " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heartbroken mum has described how she tried desperately to warn health authorities her son was a a danger to himself, but he still managed to take his own le. Matthew Siddorn died at  years old after at least three known previous suicide attempts. Vicky Siddorn, from Bebington, Wirral, lost her son Matthew in April . Matthew left behind an identical twin brother, Daniel. The -year-old mum said Matthew was a happy, content and mischievous baby who did everything with his twin. Speaking to the Liverpool ECHO, Vicky said: Matthew was born exactly  minutes after his brother and Daniel never let him forget that. They were born four weeks early with no problems, he was just a lovely baby very content, slept right through at three weeks. Just a lovely baby, happy little boy, dead mischievous. The mum-of-three said her son excelled throughout school, but had a couple of wobbles when he was around -years-old. She added: After Matt died I have since found out that he had a couple of wobbles when he was about , but went to the doctor so he knew to ask for help. They asked himhe wanted to be referred to CAMHS but everything settled down. I am hearing voices and I am seeing a figure and itaposs telling me Iaposve got to hurt myself The former Wirral Grammar student earned a place to study Geology at Leicester University in September  - but just a few months into his first year, Vicky received a distressing phonecall while she was at work. The store healthcare assistant said she answered the phone to her son in February , telling the ECHO: I had been in work and Matthew had left a message - he was upset and distressed, so I phoned him back. He got really upset and he was crying and he said aposI need help mumapos, so I said aposokay tell meapos and he told me he had been hurting himself. He said aposI am hearing voices and I am seeing a figure and itaposs telling me Iaposve got to hurt myself or itaposs going to do stuff to my family or the people I love, Iaposm scared.apos  The -year-old told her son to come home and they visited their family GP who referred Matthew to mental health services. Vicky said due to her sonaposs conscientious nature he went back to university, but came straight back for his appointment at St Catherineaposs Hospital in Tranmere. Only  at the time, Matthew had started to self-harm, which Vicky said he was very open about with his family. He also kept a journal of his thoughts where he drew the shape he was seeing and described where he was hearing voices, which he took to the appointment. However, Vicky claims her son was only in the appointment for around  minutes. She said: I askedhe wanted me to go in with him and he said he was fine, he had his book with him. So I dropped him off and the distance in my car from my house to St Catherineaposs is less than  minutes. I literally dropped him off, he walked in and I went home and made myself a coffee. I was at home for a maximum of  minutes and I got a call from him saying he was done. The mum asked Matthew whether he had been diagnosed, given medication or a follow-up appointment. However, she claims Matthew was told he was tired and could go back to university despite showing his journal. Vicky said despite it being a little against their will Matthew went back to university and told his mumhe felt down or depressed he would visit the doctor there.  Matthewaposs first suicide attempt - a hysterical call from his twin brother and a race to hospital A week after ing to university in September , Vicky received a hysterical phone call from her son Daniel who told her his twin brother had tried to kill himself. She said: It was am and Daniel rang hysterically crying and he could not get the words out and said Matthew had tried to kill himself. One of Matthewaposs friends had tried to contact us, but weaposre ex-directory and they couldnapost get our home phone number so managed to get Danielaposs number. Vicky and her husband Steve drove straight to the hospital in Leicester, where Matthew had discharged himself due to being -years-old. She told her son he needed to come home and be under the care of family doctors and Wirral. The -year-old added: I kept blubbing and thinking the NHS will save him and thinking we will do this, we will get him help, look at me Iaposve had [depression] for nearly  years and Iaposm fine. He was just really despondent and hollow, its hard to describe until you look into their eyes. Obviously I had looked into Matthewaposs eyes for nearly  years and he always had a future, a plan, uni and loved his le and wanted to study in America. Mental health services in Wirral were contacted by the familyaposs GP, however at this point Vicky claims they were reassured the teenager didnapost have a mental health illness despite Matthew having auditory hallucinations and having made a suicide attempt, as well as self-harming. Matthew went back to Leicester where he had regular visits from doctors and counsellors, reassuring his mum he understood the gravity of his suicide attempt. Vicky said: I was a constant bag of nerves. I was having about three hours of sleep a night, I was permanently waiting for the phone to go, but I told myself Iaposve got to learn to calm down. Matthewaposs second suicide attempt - a message from his uni mates and a suicide letter left behind On Halloween , Vicky received a message from one of her sonaposs university friends saying Matthew had attempted suicide for the second time. Vicky said he pre-planned and researched his second attempt, leaving him in a secure unit in hospital. The mum-of-three also found a suicide letter. Vicky and her husband told Matthew he needed to quit university andhome to the Wirral for good. She said: We decided he had to come home and I need to be able to monitor him and go to meetings with him and he knew he needed too as well, he said aposyes I know I need to get better.apos Upon theirhome, Vicky said she phoned their GP again and made an emergency appointment with mental health services right away. The mum claims her son had an hour long appointment at Clatterbridge Hospital.  She added: I remember it being an hour as because I took a really heavy book thinking Iaposd be there for ages and looking at my watch. He came out and he was given no medication, they said he had no mental health illness and there didnapost really seem to be anything much. They said right you need to make these plans, things to look forward to. As December  rolled around, Vicky claims her son was insistent on helping his dad out at his grandmotheraposs house, only later to find out Matthew had hidden items there. The -year-old said Matthew walked the dog with her to work and they had arrangements where she would call her son to check in. She said: We had these little arrangements and I was only up the road and he seemed to be starting to look like he wanted to make plans for the future. We were still very cautious of him though and we thought mental health services were aware of him and he was seeing people. I know people are going to say - why didnapost you put him private care and I beat myself up everyday that we didnapost re-mortgage our house and that I didnapost force my way into the room into one of those meetings. Matthewaposs third suicide attempt - a worrying Facebook post and a call to police In December  Matthew  posted a cryptic message on Facebook, which a friend in Leicester spotted and managed to ring Merseyside Police before it was deleted. Matthew had made his third suicide attempt. His mum said: I was in work and my neighbours came up and said aposwe donapost want you to get too distressedapos and the minute they said that my stomach just dropped. Police had broken the door down and my boss drove me to our house. Itaposs like I revert to being a small child and perhaps a lot parents who lose children do this, you revert to wanting to be  years old again and want to run away to the park because youaposre so scared. Matthew wasnapost in his family home, but Vicky noticed the keys to her mother-in-laws house were missing. A nearby traffic officer drove to the house where he noticed blood. Matthew was found next to the fire in his grandmotheraposs house, sat on the sofa and waiting to die. Vicky said: I remember thinking now I really am scared and I donapost think anyone can save him now and then I started losing a little faith. I donapost think they understood the urgency - it was his third attempt. The -year-old claims her son was left in AE with no security in place and was left with a kne and fork. Vicky said: They had left him with the curtains that go round the bed and thick bedsheets at the end of the bed and I was sitting opposite him and I saw him look at those sheets and look at the curtain rail for a long time.  I thought I know what he is going to dohe is allowed to, he is going to do something. We had quite big discussions about it, which is pretty dark - having a conversation about your child trying to kill themself. Itaposs not a conversation you should have but then it should be at the same time. He was always very honest and open. The zone you go into he described it as a tunnel when the pain got too much and itaposs like a fog which takes over and you just do it. If it clears a little it and the pain lessens a little bit and people start talking to you, you push it away. He told me because I wanted to know, he said it was like having loads of Matthews and him - the Matthew who wants to get well canapost get out. Where is this place you think we can keep him safe  Vicky claims that a member of the mental health team arrived and said they would assess him in the morning. His shoes had been removed and the family were told security would bring him backhe tried to leave the hospital - but there were no constant checks. The next day, Vicky brought a four-page suicide note Matthew had written in to his assessment. Vicky claims she and her husband were initially denied access to the meeting but were eventually allowed to be present after insisting they should be there. The family told mental health services they couldnapost look after Matthew on their own and he needed professional help, but claim they were asked aposwhere is this place you think we can keep him safe apos Matthewaposs parents suggested the psychiatric unit at Clatterbridge Hospital, but said they were told once again he was not mentally ill and had to take him home. Mental health services agreed to contact the home team for Matthew to receive visits. Vicky claims when the home team visited they promised they could give medication and section Matthewneeded. A -hour helpline was  also provided and the family started to feel they were being taken seriously. However, she claims the home team only visited three times before Matthew was discharged without telling his parents - with his third appointment allegedly lasting five minutes. Vicky also claims Matthew was not given any medication, a diagnosis or the chance to see a psychiatrist, but was given five sessions of cognitive behavioural therapy . It was recommended that Matthew visit the gym and consider ing to university. She said: I would take him to the gym and outside because I was petried he was going to leave and go somewhere. We would talk a lot about his illness together, he said he had constant pain in his head and had no zest for le. At the end of February , Vicky managed to get Matthew to see the familyaposs GP, as she believed her son was planning another suicide attempt. Their doctor urgently requested for Matthew to see a psychiatrist, writing in a letter aposI can no longer guarantee his safety.apos Vicky claims the request was rejected, but Matthew had one final appointment at Clatterbridge for  minutes. The mum alleges she was once again told her son did not have a mental health illness because Matthew told them he wasnapost going to end his le. Itaposs awful to see police tape over your childaposs bedroom door After three suicide attempts in just a few months, Matthew took his own le on April ,  - his fourth known attempt. Vicky said: He killed himself on April ,  and itaposs awful to see police tape over your childaposs bedroom door. He died on his own in his bedroom - that breaks my heart.

title: mum who told ba crew
story: NewsMum who told BA crew you have a massive a*** must wear anti-booze braceletLondon mum-of-two Emma Langford, , drunkenly hurled abuse and pummelled cabin crew on the British Airways flight to Cape Town, South AfricaShareCommentsByJoe Morgan:,  JAN NewsEmma Langford outside court where she admitted attacking BA staff on a plane " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA single mum who went on a drunken rampage on a British Airways jumbo jet has admitted attacking cabin crew staff. Emma Langford, , has admitted attacking BA staff on the flight to Cape Town in South Africa, punching the manager and kicking another in the back of the legs while screaming: “You have a massive ar*e.” She faces jail and must wear an anti-booze bracelet after her case was adjourned so the court could seek evidence she is seeking treatment for her alcoholism. During the incident, the mum-of-two had pulled out trays of stowed plates and glasses, causing them to shatter on the floor and cutting another member of staff before pummeling cabin crew. She eventually had to be restrained with the help of an off-duty police officer on the flight before being carried off the plane when it touched down in Cape Town. Langford had previously pleaded guilty to charges of three assaults, criminal damage, being drunk on an aircraft, and behaving in a threatening manner towards cabin crew. She faces up to two years imprisonment. Isleworth Crown Court heard how Langford, as part of matters relating to the custody of her two young sons, is now accompanied by a woman who observes her  hours a day and lives in her Old Baising, Hampshire home to ensure she does not drink alcohol. The -year-old is also to wear a SCRAM bracelet, a device that is able to detect alcohol in the system every half an hour.  Both the prosecutor and defence sought to adjourn the matter for a pre-sentence report to be completed and for the court to receive a letter from her psychiatrist. Prosecutor Douglas Adams said: “Ms Langford was on a British Airways flight to Cape Town, South Africa, when she assaulted three members of the cabin crew, broke crockery and glassware, and behaved in a threatening way to several members of the cabin crew. “She was flying to South Africa to attend a rehabilitation centre to seek treatment for her addiction. “She has two recent convictions for drinking and driving.” Guy Wyatt, defending Langford, said: “It’s a mystery why no one prior to this hearing made a pre-sentence report.  “There are mental health dficulties and a serious history of alcohol abuse at play here. “It’s my application for a full pre-sentence report to be completed. I acknowledge the case law is severe. It makes it clear that it’s a rare thing for anything other than a custodial sentence. “An immediate custodial sentence is the starting point. “This lady had a plan to go to an alcohol rehabilitation centre. It’s not been a story of success, unfortunately. “In the next few days, she’s going to be fitted with a SCRAM bracelet. It may be in the interest of the criminal courts to order this be observed.  “The bracelet has a sensor that reads alcohol in the sweat and makes a report every  minutes. “It arose from family proceedings of custody of her two children. She has two young sons. “The court will be assisted to see the observations of this bracelet, consulting reports of her psychiatrist and evidence from her sober companion. “She lives at her home, and is with her  hours a day. “If anyone can come back from this, it’s this lady.”  At Langford’s previous hearing at Ealing Magistrates Court on December , her actions were deemed “so serious” that she must be sentenced at a crown court. Recorder Joseph Boothby said: “It seems to me that you have a background and history the court will want to know before I consider the extreme measure of sentencing you to prison.

story: NewsSingle mum turns house in worst ever state into a chic haven in just two monthsLauren Grfin, from Kent, was forced to rent the rundown property after her landlord decided to sell up and she was unable to find a guarantor for a nicer home as her mum was made redundantShareCommentsByLorraine King:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsShe has been praised online for her work " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA single mum forced to rent a rundown property after losing her house just before Christmas has turned it into a beautul home on a shoestring budget. Lauren Grfin, , from Kent, was dealt a huge blow when her landlord told her he would be selling the property so she would need to move. Her mum, who was her acting guarantor, was then made redundant. This meant the mum-of-two was left in hell as she was only able to afford a property in terrible condition. Lauren found a house in the worst state ever but was determined to give it a makeover in time for her and her two sons to enjoy at Christmas.She revealed the incredible transformation in Facebook group DIY on a Budget where members show the fruits of their labour while spending as little cash as possible. Lauren posted in the group: Living in private rented as a single mum Iaposve always used my mum as a guarantor.  aposThis October I was given notice to move out due to landlord selling up just after my mum got made redundant. Unable to rent anywhere  I had to take on the only place I could get through someone I knew that was in the worst state ever barely even habitable with two boys.  Itaposs been hell on earth and real testing times turning this place around quickly to make the nicest home possible for my boys in time for Christmas. Lauren told FEMAIL it said it took around two months to carry out the transformation. She painted the rooms in the propertyaposs bleak and depressing rooms and added new furniture including a table and chest of drawers in the living room. Blued LED lighting was added to the staircase, which had its banisters repainted, and to the bathroom which also had new laminated floors installed. Lauren replaced the dirty carpet in her bedroom with a new grey one and soft furnishing additions such as new cushions, curtains and rugs completed the new look.She said: Thereaposs still a long way to go and far from perfect, but today I am proud of how far I have come on a tight budget. title: sas sent iraq evacuate brits
story: NewsSAS sent to Iraq to evacuate Brits from terror hotspot as Iran tensions soarEXCLUSIVE: The SAS have been forced to move into Iraq to helpBritish people after a US air strike killed a high-ranking Iranian generalShareCommentsBySean RaymentAlan Selby:,  JAN NewsThe SAS are heading out to the Middle East as tensions soar following the US assassination of Iran’s top military commander" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe SAS are heading out to the Middle East tonight for a ­possible rescue mission as ­tensions soared after the US killed Iran’s top military man. Britain’s most elite forces have been mobilised in the wake of President Trump’s ­ordering the assassination of General Qassem Soleimani, . He died in a Reaper drone missile strike near Baghdad airport in ­neighbouring Iraq on Friday. It is understood around  members of the Special Air Service and the Navy’s Special Boat Service along with the Special Forces Support Group will be sent to Iraq to help any possible ­evacuation of Britons in the region. There are at least , military and UK government civilian personnel in Iraq as part of Operation Shader which is the UK mission to help train Iraqi and Kurdish forces defeat Islamic State. Boris Johnson is expected toto London from ­holiday in time for ministerial meetings in No on Monday amid fears of all-out war breaking out in the Gulf.It is understood defence chiefs have ordered British troops in Iraq – numbering around  – to be on high alert following the assassination. Senior commanders are concerned that British nationals could be targeted by Iranian-backed Shia militia groups based inside Iraq. Soleimani was the head of Iran’s elite Quds Force and mastermind of Iran’s Middle East operations. He has been blamed for the deaths and maiming of thousands of British and American troops in operations across the Middle East over decades. One senior UK defence source said: “Soleimani was an enemy combatant in  a war zone who was deploying to oversee and orchestrate Iranian ­operations in a foreign country which would have resulted in the deaths of US soldiers, ­civilians and potentially British personnel as well.  “He knew the risks and took his chances as all troops do and he paid the price.  “Soleimani had been a marked man for quite a while. He had the blood of many British soldiers on his hands. “The attack was all about sending a message to the Iranian leadership and that is that the US can get at you at any time and in any place.” Last night several rockets landed near the US embassy in Baghdad, injuring five people. Three more rockets were reportedly fired at Balad Airbase housing American troops north of Baghdad. In another development Defence Secretary Ben Wallace announced British warships would resume ­operations in the Strait of Hormuz. HMS Montrose and HMS Defender are already in the Gulf and will act as escorts to British tankers to prevent them being seized by Iran’s navy. Mr Wallace said: “The Government will take all necessary steps to protect our ships and citizens at this time.” At least  targets in the US and Israel have been identied by Iran for retaliatory strikes after the country’s president vowed to exact revenge for the killing of General Soleimani. Targets include ships in the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz and Tel Aviv. The US State Department said: “General Soleimani was actively developing plans to ­attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region.”  Thousands of mourners chanted “Death to America” yesterday as they marched in Soleimani’s funeral procession in Baghdad as US and UK flags were publicly burned. It is feared that all-out war could break out in the regionIran calls on its allies Russia and China to help as tensions rise. The Foreign Office yesterday strengthened its warnings over travel to the Middle East. British nationals were advised not to travel to Iraq or Iran. The Foreign Office warned that anyone in Iraq outside the Kurdistan region should consider leaving by ­commercial means because the ­uncertain security situation could ­deteriorate quickly. Alerts regarding other Middle East nations were also being increased, with warnings that Britons should remain vigilant in Afghanistan, Israel, Lebanon and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab , who will visit the US next week to meet with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in a previously planned visit, said: “The first job of any Government is to keep British people safe.” An American official denied the nation was behind a second air strike on two vehicles north of Baghdad. Iraq’s state TV reported that the attack killed six people in a medical convoy.US president Donald Trump said his order to kill Soleimani was “to stop a war, not to start one”.Back in  Soleimani was involved in backing pro-Iranian militia groups in southern Iraq. These factions targeted British troops with bombs and rockets, killing and maiming a signicant number. In response the SAS set up a special operation to wipe out the Iranian-backed cells. But a mission to kill Soleimani was reportedly blocked by David Miliband, then Foreign Secretary. A British military source said: “The Foreign Secretary said that he wanted to talk to the Iranians, not kill them. “We had Soleimani in our ­crosshairs, but we had to call the operation off because of sensitivities in London about conducting this type of operation.” There has been criticism of the US for not giving advanced notice of the attack to the UK. Former Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the failure to noty was regrettable because allies should ensure there are no surprises in the relationship.Mr Hunt said: “This is a very, very risky situation, and I think the job that we have to do as one of the US’s closest allies is to use our influence.” Friday’s attack also killed four Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guards and five of Iraq’s pro-Iran paramilitaries.

title: cammy its time dee realise how good they can be
story: Cammy Kerr says it’s time the Dundee squad realised how good they can be as they embark on what they plan is a positive .The Dark Blues ended  on a positive note after a strong showing in a - draw at rivals Dundee United followed up back-to-back wins against Dunfermline and Partick.After a calendar year to forget at Dens Park, Kerr plans to use their recent good run to hit the ground running for the second half of the campaign, starting tomorrow at home to Inverness.He told the Tele: “ wasn’t a good year.“Even as a young boy coming through when my first season full-time was the ‘Club ’ season. That was a dficult time.“We’ve had loads of ups and downs but the past year is certainly one, for the first half of it anyway, we want to put behind us as quickly as possible.“With the recent bit of form and positivity, we take that into  and kick on.”Dundee start the year with three home matches on the bounce, firstly against potential play-off rivals Caley Thistle and Ayr United before they welcome high-flying Premiership side Motherwell to Dens Park for a Scottish Cup tie.“We have dficult games coming up. We have three games at home now and we need to get back to making this place a fortress,” Kerr added.“I said it at the start of the season that,we wanted to do anything in this league, we’ve got to make our home form much better than it has been.“It is better than it has been over the past year but it’s still not where we want it to be.“That’s something we are working so hard every day to put right.“Every game we go into, we expect ourselves to win. That’s not being arrogant or cocky but what Dundee should be aiming for.“There needs to be a realisation of how good this squad can be.”And Kerr says the second half against league leaders United last Friday gives everyone associated with the club belief they can start looking upwards.“There was a wee realisation after the game we could have taken three points.“The boys have spoken since and we’re starting to realise how well we can do as a team.“After we got the goal at Tannadice, there was a belief on the pitch and I think the fans felt that.“Even when the board went up for how long was left, the fans still thought we could win it.“Hopefully, that is a wee turning point for us – it needs to be going forward.“There has been a lot of disappointment, a lot of games where we have huffed and puffed throughout the season.“Last Friday, the fans came again in their numbers and I didn’t expect there to be so many, to be honest.“United had three of the stands but our fans were so loud again and when we scored it was great to go and celebrate with them.“Our fans have had to endure a dficult year, especially with United being on top since day one.“We are happy with how it went but, at the same time, we need to make sure we don’t rest on a draw – we need to remember we didn’t win – but use it to kick us on.”Dundee have faced the Caley Jags three times this season, winning -, drawing - and losing - last time in Inverness.Dundee United - Dundee: Dorrans# first goal earns Dee derby point" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united---dundee-dorrans-first-goal-earns-dee-derby-point embed # secretynOUlpvmC" data-secret"ynOUlpvmC" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Kerr added: “We are under no illusions how tough it will be tomorrow. Inverness are second for a reason.“They beat us last time. I was on the bench that day but the boys won’t mind me saying we didn’t do ourselves justice.“We huffed and puffed, had loads of possession but we weren’t good enough on the day to be the team everyone wants us to be – we need to make up for that.”

story: Greg Stewart or Johnny Russell  Gary Mackay-Steven or Gary Harkins  Darren O’Dea or Sean Dillon Who is the best we’ve seen in the City of Discovery over the past  years As we head into the s, Tele Sport writers George Cran and Calum Woodger looked back over the decade and, after a debate on the Twa Teams, One Street podcast, brought together the EveningTeam of the Decade.Goalkeeper: Scott BainArriving at Dens Park a year before the club won the Championship, Bain made himself club No  in the Premiership.After  appearances for the club, Bain left for Celtic and has played three times for Scotland.Defence: Gary IrvineA favourite among Dundee fans who crowned Irvine ‘the White Cafu’ after a flurry of goals from right-back, the defender made almost  appearances for the club.Defenders: Sean DillonA modern day club legend, ‘Dillo’ spent more than  years at Dundee United, winning the Scottish Cup in .He went on to captain the club for four seasons in the top-flight before departing in  after making  appearances in tangerine.James McPakeDillon and McPake shook hands six times as captains in Dundee derbies, with the United man getting the better of the results.McPake, though, is remembered as a player for two derby goals – one in a - title: dundee united 1 1 dundee dorrans first goal earns dee derby point
story: Graham Dorrans# first goal for Dundee earned his side a point as they came from behind at Tannadice to end Dundee United#s derby dominance.Nicky Clark had given league leaders United an early advantage but Dorrans rled home the equaliser in the second period to end the Terrors# nine-game winning streak and perfect derby record this season.Dundee were unchanged from their win over Partick last weekend while Louis Appere replaced the injured Sam Stanton for United.And it was the Tangerines who got off to a dream start in front of a , near-sell-out, scoring with the first attack and shot of the game after just five minutes.Appere released Jamie Robson on the overlap down the left and the full-back#s delivery was flicked home by Clark for his seventh goal of the season.Action threatened to boil over on  minutes as Robson and Dundee#s Paul McGowan exchanged handbags in the corner but referee Alan Muir kept his cards in his pocket.And it was McGowan who had the Dark Blues# first real chance of the game on  minutes.The -year-old picked up on a Jordan Marshall cut back, twisted and turned in the box to make some space but saw his shot deflected behind for a corner.On  minutes McGowan was again denied by Siegrist inside the box as he collected a lovely reverse pass from -year-old Fin Robertson but couldn#t find a way past the big Swiss.Terrors talisman Lawrence Shankland had his first clear-cut chance of the game  minutes before half-time but couldn#t head home from six yards out after Robson#s delivery.Calum Butcher escaped a booking on two counts as he went in heavy on Danny Johnson and McGowan as tempers began to flare as the game approached half-time.Dee keeper Jack Hamilton did well to deny Ian Harkes from close range to keep the score down at the interval.Much like the opening period, there was an early goal to start the second half # and it was Dundee who got it.Five minutes after the action restarted Dorrans got on the end of Liam Smith#s clearance to rle home a left-footed volley for his first goal for the club.With the match level, the Dark Blues almost took the lead moments later as Johnson was inches away from getting on the end of a Sean Mackie cross.On  minutes, Shankland went close as he nodded Paul McMullan#s cross just wide of Hamilton#s left-hand post as both teams pushed for a winner.However, both sides had to settle for a point apiece as they go into the new year United sitting top and Dundee in play-off contention.Dundee United XI : SiegristL Smith, Watson, Reynolds , Robson Butcher, Harkes, McMullan, Clark , Appere Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Connolly, C Smith, Chalmers, King and Mochrie.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, McGhee, Meekings , Marshall McGowan, Robertson, Dorrans, Mackie Hemmings, Johnson .Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Todd, Byrne, Moore and Mulligan.Ref: Alan Muir.Att: , .

He said: #My predictions for  would be an increase in the level of electric vehicles across Scotland with a wider infrastructure being applied.#Also, on a much more exciting note there will be an opportunity to introduce hydrogen buses. #We#re going to take  buses and put them on the roads in Dundee and have zero emissions and the hope is that we#ll have jobs coming out of it.#Lauren Morsley, , an employee at Lush, said: #A lot more people are conscious about eating more plant based foods, cutting down on the amount of meat and animal products they consume.#With soaps that#s the easiest part to do because you can get the exact same product but without all the animal byproducts in it. That resource pressure could have a very big effect on people in Dundee who are already struggling.#However, some are more optimistic about the city#s future.Sara White, ,  an employee at Tartan House of Scotland, said: #I think that between the cruise ships coming in for the VA and restaurants opening up and more tourist type shops like this one, we will hopefully see an increase in people coming into the city centre and spending their money.#

title: national organisation thanks dundee mum for breast milk donation after seeing tele story
story: A national organisation has thanked a young Dundee mum for donating breast milk, after seeing an article on the Tele website.Shelby O#Shea decided to give back to Dundee#s Ninewells Hospital after medics saved her daughter Maëva Aaliyah#s le.Shelby had a brush with death for both her and Maëva after she suffered from pre-eclampsia.The incident has inspired Shelby to make a New Year#s resolution to help others as much as she possibly can.Shelby, , from Lochee, gave birth to her baby on December  after an emergency Cesarean section at Ninewells.The lives of both mum and daughter were at risk and Maëva was delivered within an hour of Shelby going into hospital.She was born weighing only lbs one oz but apart from initial support with her breathing she was fit and well and healthy and has since gone from strength-to-strength, although she won#t be allowed out of hospital until some time in January.Dundee mum donates her own breast milk to the hospital that saved her baby" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp new-mum-donates-her-own-breast-milk-to-hospital-that-saved-her-baby embed # secretEIYjHPlj" data-secret"EIYjHPlj" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Shelby too has made a quick recovery and decided to try to give something back to the hospital and support other mums and babies at the same time.She said that she was lucky to be producing a lot of milk to feed Maeva, so much in fact that she reckons she has some to spare.She said: #I have so much milk that another little baby could benefit from.#Seeing Maëva so small, premature and relying on my milk to survive more than anything it#s truly inspired me.#I’d love to help another baby in Maëva#s position whose mummy can’t give them that benefit of their own milk.#My  resolution is to make a dference to as many lives  as possible and give all I can to everyone I can help.#Le is far too short, you never know when your time is up, so make every day count and most importantly make a dference in the world any chance you get, it’s the littlest things that mean the most.#Commenting on the article on Facebook, a spokeswoman from Milk Bank Scotland, which is based in Glasgow#s NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, said: #Thanks for the lovely story and article.#It’s so great to hear of your success in providing breast milk for both your own baby and to the milk bank.#The Scotland-wide donor milk bank service was officially launched in June .It benefits more than  of the most vulnerable babies a year, allowing them to be fed breastmilk for a longer period of time to reduce their health risks associated with being sick and premature.It will also help babies whose mothers have early feeding challenges, as they are able to get access to the donor breastmilk.The Scottish Donor Milk Bankcollects, screens, stores, processes and distributes donor breast milkto be fed to another mother’s child.All requests for donor milk from all neonatal units across Scotland are met.Donor milk is transported safely from donors homes to the DMB and from there to neonatal units across Scotland by the Glasgow Children’s Charity Volunteer Drivers.

title: north east towns cctv upgrade to be finished next month
story: Work on a north-east town’s CCTV network will be completed by the end of next month.Plans for a network of new cameras to cover Fraserburgh town centre were approved by the council earlier this month.The Fraserburgh CCTV Working Group applied for permission to set up six new cameras to replace the previous set up which was ageing.Three dome-style cameras are to be installed at Broad Street with the others at Garden’s pharmacy on Mid Street, Fraserburgh bus station and at the Old Parish Church on Barrasgate Road.Two of the cameras would be placed on poles and Aberdeen Technical Services Ltd has been selected to carry out the work.Brian Topping, chairman of the Fraserburgh CCTV Working Group, said businesses in the port have been quick to back the scheme and said the support for it has been “tremendous”.Mr Topping said: “We are looking to have this done by the end of January or start of February. Some of the cameras have already been upgraded and we are now waiting to get the ones placed on poles finished.“I am very grateful that everything has been approved.“The response to this project has been tremendous.“We hope this will encourage more people to come into our town centre and use the facilities.”Fraserburgh CCTV Working Group was given a £, grant by the council in  to upgrade the decades-old camera network.To secure the funds they needed to raise £, themselves.Mr Topping said there would be no stopping the CCTV group’s fundraising efforts as they look to bring in cash to help with the running costs.He said: “We are desperate to bring in more CCTV money so we can operate the system and pay for repairs.“We are so grateful to everybody who has donated already.”

title: legend clark says time onside of dons as stars are lured south
story: Pittodrie legend Bobby Clark insists Aberdeen face a challenge to hold onto their starsEnglish clubs come calling.The January transfer window has now opened and English clubs are expected to step up their interest in leading scorer Sam Cosgrove and Scotland international defender Scott McKenna.Former Dons and Scotland keeper Clark insists the cash power of clubs south of the border due to television finance makes it an uphill task for Scottish clubs like Aberdeen to retain their top talent.However, Clark insists eventhe Reds cannot retain their star players long term, the club is still set up to deliver success due to the management team in place.The -year-old said: “If you bring players through and make them into top players it is much harder to hold onto them now than before the Bosman rule.“It is hard for Scottish teams to compete with the English Premier League because of the television money.“That is a challenge for Aberdeen. However, Aberdeen have the right people in charge and are built to deliver success.“The facilities at Cormack Park are great, but ultimately it is the people that matter.“I am a great believer in people. Aberdeen have the right people with Derek McInnes, Tony Dochertyand Gordon Marshall .“They have a really good first team squad and then there is Neil Simpson .”The Bosman ruling was passed by the European Court of Justice in  and ruled that clubs no longer had to pay transfer fees after the expiration of a player’s contract.The rule was the result of Belgian midfielder Jean-Marc Bosman’s fight against his then-employer RFC Liege.Before the Bosman ruling, a player could not leave at the end of their deal unless that club agreed to let him go on a free, or that club received an agreed fee from a buying club. The Bosman ruling allowed a player to leave a club on a free transfer as soon as their contract expired.That flipped the balance of power as players now had leverage to demand signing-on fees and salaries from new clubs to make up for absent transfer fee.Players coming to the end of their contract could also ask for more money from their current club, who would fear losing that player on a free.Aberdeen are in the driving seat with Cosgrove and McKenna as both are secured on long-term contracts.Middlesbrough, Derby County and Stoke City are tracking prolic scorer Cosgrove, who became the first Aberdeen player to net  goals before Christmas since Duncan Shearer in .Cosgrove is contracted until the summer of , having signed an extension last January.QPR are also reportedly set to step up their interest in centre-back McKenna after having a bid rejected towards the English summer transfer deadline.Aberdeen had rejected a £.m bid from Aston Villa for McKenna the previous summer window.McKenna is contracted to Aberdeen until summer .Capped  times for Scotland, McKenna is a product of the Pittodrie youth system and recently made his th appearance for the Reds. Clark is confident Aberdeen’s youth system will continue to produce first-team talent.He believes the £m Cormack Park, which is home to the Bobby Clark Football Academy, will be fundamental to that.He said: “Cormack Park can help bring through young players and it is great that Neil Simpson is now the director of coaching.“When I think back to Simmy, he was the first boy that progressed from the schoolboy coaching into Aberdeen’s ranks.“For him to have made that jump and then to have played as well as he did, to now be running it, is absolutely fantastic.”Signed in , Clark won all three domestic trophies with Aberdeen.Capped  times for Scotland, he was part of the  World Cup squad in Argentina.

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#
